title: Entrepreneurial Performance
abstractText:
Due to their role in creating jobs, in getting new products to the market, and in increasing product market competition, entrepreneurs are often regarded as essential to long-term economic performance for a country or region. While economists and sociologists have undertaken considerable research on the transition to entrepreneurship, much less is known about entrepreneurial performance.

This project studies the returns to entrepreneurship through use of a novel and unique dataset from Norway. The dataset contains close to 10,000 start-ups and is free for survivorship bias. It provides rich information on start-up accounting performance and on founder work experience (and wages) before, during and even after the life of the start-up.

Some of the questions examined are:

  • What are the opportunity-cost adjusted economic returns to entrepreneurship?
  • What is the relative impact of founder human capital and other factors such as wealth on entrepreneurial performance?
  • What type of human capital is more detrimental to entrepreneurial success?
  • How are start-ups financed, and which factors can explain their access and use of finance?

It is believed that the project will produce knowledge relevant to nascent entrepreneurs, financiers, and to policy makers interested in whether the economic incentives to start up new companies are sufficient.
impactText: One of the objectives of the research was to investigate the role of liquidity (personal wealth) for entrepreneurial performance. I found a surprising inverse U-shaped relationship that has received considerable interest among researchers and policy makers. I also explored the importance of the entrepreneur for start-up performance, a study that has also been widely covered by international press and cited. findingsText:
One of the objectives of the research was to investigate the role of liquidity (personal wealth) for entrepreneurial performance. I found a surprising inverse U-shaped relationship that has received considerable interest among researchers and policy makers. I also explored the importance of the entrepreneur for start-up performance, a study that has also been widely covered by international press and cited.
